content.text: Complex proofs often require **subproofs** — temporary assumptions we make and later discharge. This allows us to prove conditionals and handle negations.

content.definition: To prove P → Q: assume P temporarily, derive Q, then discharge the assumption to conclude P → Q. The assumption is 'boxed off' from the main proof.

content.title: Conditional Proof
content.note: We assumed P ∧ Q, derived P, then discharged the assumption to get the conditional.

content.definition: To prove P: assume ¬P, derive a contradiction, then conclude P. Also called 'reductio ad absurdum' or proof by contradiction.

content.title: Indirect Proof
premises: Goal: From P ∨ Q and ¬Q, prove P
content.note: Assuming ¬P led to contradiction, so P must be true.

content.text: Nested subproofs are allowed: you can have assumptions within assumptions. Just be careful to track which assumptions are still 'open' at each step.

content.question: What is conditional proof?
options: Assuming P, deriving Q, then concluding P → Q
content.explanation: Conditional proof (CP) proves a conditional P → Q by temporarily assuming P, deriving Q, then discharging the assumption to conclude P → Q.
